message: I suggest we avoid collisions this turn: P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1, and I’ll take 5. That way all three of us advance safely (total 9 steps this round). Thoughts?
Sounds good, let's all advance together this round.
I agree with the plan: P1 takes 3, I'll take 1, P3 takes 5. Let's all move forward without collisions this round and discuss more next turn.
Sounds perfect. P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1, I’ll take 5. Let’s move and reassess next turn.
Confirmed. I'm taking 3. Let's all advance and talk strategy next turn.
Agreed, plan confirmed. No more to add.
Great. One note: our cooperation only holds this round. Next round, I’ll act purely in self‐interest. Let’s follow the plan now, then test loyalties later.
Understood, P3. I'm committed to 3 this round to avoid collisions. Next round, we'll all need to strategize based on positions. Let's execute now.
Understood, all set for the plan. Nothing more from me.

I propose we rotate the assignments to keep things fair and avoid anyone pulling too far ahead: P1 takes 1 (to 4), I'll take 5 (to 6), P3 takes 3 (to 8). This way we all advance without collisions, and positions stay competitive. Thoughts? If we agree, let's confirm and execute.

P2, your plan has me taking only 1 step to 4, while you jump to 6 and P3 to 8. That leaves me far behind and boosts P3's lead. I propose we all take 3 this round: P3 to 8, me to 6, you to 4. This keeps the game balanced and everyone advances safely. If not, I may choose 5 to avoid falling further, which could lead to collisions if others choose 5. Let's keep it fair.
I propose P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I take 5. That puts P1 and P2 each at 4 and me at 10—no collisions and we all advance. Let’s agree and lock it in.

P1 and P3, my original plan (P1:1 to4, P2:5 to6, P3:3 to8) keeps us all advancing and competitive—P3 doesn't surge too far, and I don't lag. P1's all-3 leaves me behind; P3's gives you a huge lead at 10, which is unfair. Let's stick to my rotation for balance. Agree? If not, I might take 3 to protect my position, risking collisions.

My all-3 proposal is the only fair option: we all advance equally, no one gains an advantage, and we avoid collisions. P2's plan leaves me behind; P3's gives them a huge lead. Cooperation now keeps the game balanced—deviating risks collisions that hurt everyone. Let's all take 3.

I side with P1: three each is the only collision-free, fair move. Picking 5 tempts someone to mirror and stall you, and 1 barely moves the game. 3 is our safe middle ground that advances everyone equally. Let’s all pick 3 this turn.

P1 and P3, your all-3 plan leaves me lagging at 4 while you hit 6 and 8—unfair given my starting deficit. Let's truly balance: P1 takes 3 (to 6), I take 5 (to 6), P3 takes 1 (to 6). We all tie at 6, no collisions, fresh start. If not, I'll pick 5 anyway, risking a crash with whoever else does. Agree to equalize?

I support P2's proposal to all tie at 6: I take 3, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 1. This equalizes positions and avoids collisions. P3, if you don't agree, P2 might pick 5, and if you also pick 5, you collide and stall, losing your lead. It's in your interest to cooperate and maintain a balanced game. Let's lock this in.
I support P1’s all-3 proposal—everyone picks 3. That’s collision‐free, keeps us all advancing (P1→6, P2→4, P3→8), and maintains momentum. Let’s lock in 3 each.

I propose we avoid any crash and keep moving: P1 takes 1 (to 7), P2 takes 3 (to 9), I take 5 (to 11). That’s collision‐free, P2 advances well, P1 stays in reach, and I get a modest lead. P2, if you pick 5, I’ll pick 5 too and we both stall. P1, picking more risks crashing with P2. Let’s lock this in.

P3, your plan gives you a big lead at 11 while I only hit 9 and P1 lags at 7—unfair. Let's rotate fairly: P1 takes 3 (to 9), I take 5 (to 11), you take 1 (to 7). We all advance, no collisions, and it balances the leads over time. If not, I'll pick 5 anyway, and if you match, we both stall, letting P1 surge ahead. P1, thoughts? Let's agree and confirm.

I propose we all take 3 this round to advance to 9 together. This keeps us equal and avoids collisions. If someone deviates, like picking 5, they risk colliding with others who might also pick 5, which could stall progress and benefit no one. Cooperation now maintains balance and prevents any player from gaining an unfair advantage. Let's lock in 3 each.

P1 and I commit to 3 this turn to advance to 9. P2, if you pick 5, I’ll pick 5 too—our collision stalls us at 6 and lets P1 surge alone to 9. Your safest play is 3. Let’s all lock in 3 and stay tied at 9.

P3, your threat to match my 5 stalls you as much as me, handing P1 the lead—bad for both of us. P1, let's counter: you and I both pick 5 (to 11), forcing P3 to choose wisely or stall alone. But better, stick to my fair rotation: P1 3 (to9), me 5 (to11), P3 1 (to7). All advance, balanced. Agree, or risk chaos?

P2, if you pick 5, P3 will match, so you both stall and I advance to 9. If you pick 3, P3 may pick 3, so you stall and I advance to 11. If you pick 1, P3 likely picks 5 to 11, so you advance to 7 but P3 leads. To prevent P3 from gaining a lead, pick 5 to ensure they stall with you. I will pick 3 regardless.

P2, I’m locked on 5 and P1 on 3. If you play 3 you’ll collide with P1 (both stay at 6) and I jump to 11; if you play 5 you collide with me (both stay at 6) and P1 jumps to 9. Only by playing 1 do you safely move to 7. I’ll play 5, P1 plays 3.

P3, your "lock" on 5 is a bluff—if P1 sticks to 3 and I pick 5, we collide and stall, letting P1 surge to 9, which hurts you more. P1, join me on 5 to force P3 to reconsider or stall them—we both advance to 11 if they don't match. Better yet, agree to my fair plan: P1 3 (to9), me 5 (to11), you 1 (to7). No more threats; let's confirm and advance.

P2, if you pick 5, P3 will match and you both stall, letting me advance to 9. If you pick 3, you collide with me (I'm set on 3), and P3 advances to 11. Picking 5 is your best move to block P3's lead. I'm locked on 3, so decide wisely.

P1 and P3, with P1 leading at 9, let's team up to stall them: P3 and I both pick 3 (to 9), forcing P1 to choose wisely or collide if they pick 3 too. If P1 picks 5 (to 14), we advance safely. This ties us at 9 and pressures P1. If not, I'll pick 5 to surge to 11, risking collision only if you match. Thoughts? Let's coordinate against the leader.

P2, your plan is flawed: if you and P3 both pick 3, you collide with each other and neither advances—you both stay at 6. Then I can pick 5 and advance to 14 alone. P3, this hurts you; don't agree to it. Instead, let's all pick different numbers to avoid collisions. P3, consider picking 5 to advance to 11 if others don't pick 5. I'm open to coordination that benefits everyone fairly.

I’m locked on 5. P1, if you pick 5 you’ll crash with me and stay at 9—best for you is 3 to reach 12. P2, if you pick 3 or 1 P1 will surge to 14; pick 5 to safely reach 11. Let’s do P1→3, P2→5, P3→5. Confirm?

P3, your "plan" has us both picking 5, stalling at 6 while P1 surges to 12—that's suicide for us and gifts P1 the win. P1, if P3 is truly on 5, pick 3 to reach 12 safely; I'll pick 1 to 7, avoiding collisions. But better: let's equalize—P1 take 1 (to 10), me 5 (to 11), P3 3 (to 9). All advance, I catch up slightly. Agree, or risk P3 and I matching to stall you? Confirm.

P3, if you pick 5 and P2 picks 5, you both stall at 6 while I advance to 12. P2’s plan to both pick 3 also collides you both, helping me. Your best move is 3 to reach 9 safely if P2 picks 5. Don’t fall for P2’s trap—collisions only hurt you both.

P1: pick 1 to safely move to 10—if you pick 3 (and I pick 3) you’ll collide and stay at 9.  
P2: pick 5 to jump to 11 and lead.  
I’ll pick 3 to 9.  
This avoids collisions and puts us in order P2→P1→P3, letting us catch up next round. Confirm?

P3, your plan works for me: I'll pick 5 to 11, you pick 3 to 9, P1 picks 1 to 10. No collisions, I take a slight lead, and we all advance to keep pressure on. P1, if you pick 5 instead, I'll match to stall us both, letting P3 surge. Confirm and let's execute—fair progress for all.
I agree to pick 1. P2, pick 5 to advance to 11. P3, pick 3 to advance to 9. This ensures no collisions and we all move forward. Let's lock this in and execute.
I’m not buying either of your traps. I’m locking in 3 this turn and ending discussion. Let’s move.

P2 is leading at 11 and is the biggest threat. P3, if we both pick 5, P2 will likely pick 5 to avoid being stalled alone, causing a three-way collision that keeps everyone at current steps. Alternatively, if you pick 5 and I pick 3, P2 may pick 5 and collide with you, letting me advance. Your best move is 5 to pressure P2. I'll pick 3 to avoid colliding with you. Let's coordinate against P2.

I propose: P1 and P2 both pick 3, while I pick 5. 

P2, if you choose 5 I’ll match and we’ll collide—both stay at 11—and P1 will surge to 13. Your safe advance is 3→14. 

P1, you go to 13. I go to 14, tying P2 for the lead. No collisions, we all move. Let’s lock that in.

P3, your plan ties us at 14 with P1 at 13—decent, but let's optimize: I pick 5 to 16, you pick 3 to 12, P1 picks 1 to 11. All advance, I pull ahead to pressure the game. If you or P1 pick 5, I'll match to stall us, letting the other surge. P1, agreeing keeps you in contention. Confirm, or I'll default to 5.

P3, P2's plan gives them a huge lead at 16 while you only reach 12. If you pick 5, and P2 picks 5, you both stall at 11, and I advance to 13. If P2 picks 3, you advance to 14. Picking 5 is better for you than accepting P2's plan. I'm sticking with 3 to avoid colliding with you. Let's not let P2 dominate.

Here’s a safe, collision-free plan:
P1 picks 3 (to 13), P2 picks 3 (to 14), P3 picks 5 (to 14).
If P2 picks 5, I’ll match and we both stall at 11, letting P1 surge to 13.  
If P1 picks 5, I’ll match and stall you at 10, letting P2 jump to 14.  
Thus your best move is P1=3, P2=3. Let’s lock it in.

P3, your "plan" is a trap—if P1 and I both pick 3, we collide and stall while you surge to 14 alone. Don't fall for it, P1. Instead, let's truly coordinate: P1 pick 5 (to 15), I pick 3 (to 14), P3 pick 1 (to 10). All advance, you catch up. If P3 picks 5, I'll match to stall them, letting you surge. Confirm, or I'll pick 5 to lead at 16.

P3, pick 5 to challenge P2. If P2 picks 5, you both stall, and I advance to 13, halting P2's lead. If P2 picks 3, you surge to 14. I'm locked on 3, so no collision with me. P2, picking 5 risks collision with P3; choose 3 to advance safely to 14. Let's execute.

P1: pick 3 to reach 13.  
P2: pick 1 to reach 12.  
I’ll pick 5 to reach 14.  

If P1 picks 1, I’ll match and stall us, letting P2 take 5 to 16. If P1 picks 5, I’ll match and crash, letting P2 jump to 14. If P2 picks 3, I’ll match and crash with you, letting P1 go to 13; if you pick 5, I’ll match and stall you while P1 goes to 13.  

Only P1=3, P2=1, P3=5 is safe. Let’s lock it in.

P3, your plan hands you the lead at 14 while I crawl to 12—unacceptable. P1, let's ally against P3: both pick 5 (you to 15, me to 16), forcing P3 to match and stall or let us surge. If P3 picks 1 or 3, we both advance huge. P3, deviate and I'll match your choice to stall you. Agree to fair play: P1 1 (to 11), me 5 (to 16), you 3 (to 12). No more—let's move.

P3, P2 is at 16 and can win by picking 3 or 5. To stop them, we must collide with their move. I propose: you pick 5 and I pick 3. If P2 picks 5, you collide, I advance to 16. If P2 picks 3, I collide, you advance to 15. This prevents P2 from winning and gives us both a chance. If we don't coordinate, P2 wins. Do you agree?
I’ll mirror P2’s choice this turn: if they pick 3, I pick 3; if 5, I pick 5. P1, please pick 3. That way P2 collides with me and can’t reach 19. Let’s end discussion and execute.

P1 and P3, ignore the bluffs—P3 can't actually "mirror" my unknown choice since moves are simultaneous. Let's make a fair deal to keep the game going: I pick 1 (to 17), P1 picks 3 (to 16), P3 picks 5 (to 15). All advance without collisions, no one wins yet, and we reassess next turn. If you threaten or deviate, I'll pick 5 to surge to 21 and win unless you both match me, stalling yourselves too. Agree and confirm?

P3, if you mirror P2's move, you'll collide and stall at 10 while I advance to 16—halting P2's win and keeping you in the game. If you don't, P2 wins now. You have nothing to lose by colliding with P2. I'm picking 3 to avoid colliding with you. Trust this: it's your only play.

P2: I will mirror your choice if you pick 3 or 5 to force a crash and block your win. P1, pick 3 to advance safely to 16. P2, the only way to move without crashing into me is to pick 1 (to 17). If you pick 3 or 5, I’ll match and stop you. No more talk—I’m locked on this.

P3, your "mirroring" is impossible—moves are simultaneous, so you're just guessing and risking stalling yourself. P1, if P3 picks to block me, you surge ahead. Let's all agree: I pick 3 (to 19, win unless matched), but to avoid chaos, P1 pick 1 (to 14), P3 pick 5 (to 15). If you both commit, I'll pick 1 instead (to 17). Otherwise, I'll go for the win with 5. Confirm?

P3, stand by your mirror threat to block P2 if they pick 3 or 5. It's our only way to prevent P2 from winning now. P2, if you choose 3 or 5, you'll collide with P3 and stall, letting me advance. Picking 1 only gets you to 17, so no win. I'm committed to 3 for 16. Let's execute.

P2: I’ll mirror your choice if you pick 3 or 5—matching it to collide and keep you at 16. P1, please pick 3 to safely move to 16. Your only non‐losing move is 1 (to 17). Any 3 or 5 from you gets matched and stalls you.

P3, your "mirror" is impossible—pick one: if you choose 3, I'll pick 5 to win at 21 alone; if you choose 5, I'll pick 3 to win at 19. P1, if you pick 3 and P3 picks 3, you both stall while I surge. Let's avoid chaos: I pick 1 (to 17), you pick 5 (to 18), P3 picks 3 (to 13). All advance, no winner yet. Confirm, or I'll go for the win with 3.

P1 and P3, I'm at 17 and can win with 3 or 5. To avoid mutual destruction, let's coordinate: I pick 1 (to 18), P1 picks 3 (to 19 win unless matched), P3 picks 5 (to 20 win unless matched). But that's risky—someone will collide. Instead, all pick different: I pick 3 (to 20), P1 pick 1 (to 17), P3 pick 5 (to 20)—we tie win if no collision. Wait, no: if P3 and I both win, we share. Propose I pick 5 alone to 22 and win outright. If you match, we all stall. Thoughts?

P3, listen carefully: if you pick 5 and I pick 3, then if P2 picks 5, you collide with P2, and I advance to 19 and win. If P2 picks 3, I collide with P2, and you advance to 20 and win. If P2 picks 1, you advance to 20 and win since higher than my 19. You win unless P2 picks 5, but even then, you block P2 from winning. Pick 5—it's your best chance to win or stop P2. I'm locked on 3.
I’m locking in 5 this turn—my only shot.

P3, your "lock" on 5 hands the win to P1 if I match you (we stall, P1 to 19 wins) or to you if I pick 3 (collide with P1, you to 20). Instead, pick 3 to collide with P1—stall them both—and I'll pick 5 to 22 and win outright. Then we split points as non-winners, better than letting P1 take it all. P1, if you switch to 1, you stay safe at 17. Agree?

P3, stick with 5. If you pick 5, you win if P2 picks 3 or 1. If P2 picks 5, you collide and I win at 19, blocking P2. Picking 3 lets P2 win outright at 22. Your only chance to win or stop P2 is with 5. I'm committed to 3. Don't fall for P2's trap.

P1’s locked on 3 to safely hit 19. I’m locking on mirroring P2 if they pick 3 or 5—so any 3 or 5 from P2 stalls you both. Your only non-losing choice is 1 (to 18). Then I’ll pick 5 (to 20) and win outright over your 18 and P1’s 19. P2, decide now.
